Now, they issued financial securities against that home loan, which paid, let's say, an interest of 7%. And those financial securities were then sold off to other investors. So, what it did was that the bank, instead of holding the money on to its balance sheet, got the money back up front. And it could then lend the money all over again. And not just that, it bundled bunches of loans together, subprime loans. So, what also happened was because, you know, the interest in case of the investors was because a lot of these loans were subprime loans. They were essentially giving a rate of return, which was better than a lot of other loans. And, you know, these were AAA rated securities.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: Which is another thing to point out, the rating agencies were actually paid. I mean, their money came from the companies.

speaker: Guest
message: Yes. This is, you know, very interesting that the amount of money that rating agencies made on, I mean, I remember this vaguely. They made at least three times the money rating a subprime loan than a normal loan. So, hence, you know, it was in their interest to keep anyone who was issuing those securities happy. Because there were three, I think, government approved rating agencies in the US. So, you know, instead of going to one, you know, instead of, let's say, going to S&P, the guy could have gone to Moody's. Right. So, there is a fundamental problem in the entire rating game. So, because of that, so banks got the money back because of securitization, the bank no longer had to hold on to the loan on its books. Now, what that did was that, you know, the entire structure, which was in place in order to ensure that you give loans to only people who returned those loans. I mean, you had loan officers who did that sort of thing. That went out of the window, because the moment you did not have the loans on your book, you know, it did not matter, you know, anyone else. So, all those loan officers were fired and all that's there in the book. So, ultimately, because all this money was being lent, there was a huge bubble in the American housing market. Now, this is just one part of this story.

speaker: Amit Varma
message: So, the bubble was because banks kept lending to subprime customers because they could easily get the loans off their books because of high ratings given by rating agencies they were paying to begin with. Right. And a part of the reason that they could give so many loans was because of low interest rates and the easy money in the system.

speaker: Guest
message: Right. So, you know, in the US, other than home loans, there is another kind of loan called the home equity loan. So, let's say a home loan outstanding on that $150,000 house is $80,000. So, your home equity is $70,000. Right. So, you can borrow against that home equity also.

speaker: Amit Varma

speaker: Guest

speaker: Guest

message: So the government had to do something. speaker: Guest
message: So Fannie and Freddie Mac were essentially, what their role was, that largely, they bought out these securitized loans from all these guys who were making these loans. speaker: Amit Varma
message: Who would buy them and they were explicitly backed by the government. Number two, you had easy money flooding the system which was enabled by the US going off the gold standard and Nixon's decision in 1971. And what that easy money did was that because of low interest rates, people had access to a lot of money, banks and financial institutions, which they used to merrily make more of these loans. And number three, what also enabled them to make all of these loans was the fact that they were able to bundle them into these securities and sell them off further down the road to others. speaker: Guest
message: In fact, the funny thing is, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac were not government owned. I mean, a lot of people tend to… they had an implicit guarantee, which was… As it was explicit, was it implicit? It was implicit. There was never an explicit guarantee as to…

speaker: Guest

speaker: Amit Varma

speaker: Guest
message: Was more easy money, yes. So, basically, you know, if you study the financial history of the United States, they have always managed to come out of an economic crisis by spending their way out of it. So, which is precisely what they wanted to do this time around as well. So, what happened was that, you know, the economic policies which were initiated had, you know, some hope of, you know, that this was what they hoped to achieve. speaker: Amit Varma

speaker: Guest

speaker: Guest

speaker: Amit Varma

speaker: Guest
message: Exactly. speaker: Amit Varma

speaker: Guest
